resources.string: Evensong’ takes place every evening at 5.30pm you won’t have to pay anything.
There\'s bric-a-brac, second-hand furniture, vintage clothes, shoes and lots more!
You\'ll find huge range of goods from designer clothes, to one-off pieces of art, food and furnishings.
In the very same place since the 1800s, became particularly famous for its antiques in the 1950s.
Very popular covered market selling everything from clothes to food to artwork.
Greenwich Market has beautiful products from designer makers and small cottage industries.
Full of shops, restaurants and cafes. You\'ll come across street performers, gorgeous craft, antiques & jewellery.
Come for antique and vintage clothes, collectables and 20th-century design pieces.
London’s National Theatre on Southbank has plenty of free concerts Mon-Sat.
The Camden Head in Angel, which puts on free comedy nights upstairs every day of the week.
All you have to do is visit TVrecordings.com or BBC Shows to see what’s available.
Free shows during the week, impossibly cool Indie bands in leg hugging jeans.
You can see them for free in different bars around the East End.
Hear people speak their mind at Speakers’ Corner
In Bank of England you can take a grip and try to lift a golden bar.
Pop in and try 1485 Craft Lager made specifically for them.
See the giant spiders from ‘Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets’.
Have you ever cruise down in The Floating City of love and bridges?
Amazing Dutch architecture in a flower-filled field zone 2!
Do you want to see the biggest white temple built outside of India?
A slice of St Petersburg in west London. Services are mostly held in Slavonic.
London\'s largest Site of Special Scientific Interest and a European Special Area of Conservation.
The rich reds, pinks and purples of blooming rhododendrons and azaleas you have to see.
Creep through the overgrown woods of Abney Park Cemetery.
If you can’t resist squeezing lavender then you will be in your element here.
Thousands wander across Hampstead Heath\'s wild and undulating parkland every year.
You can save yourself the price of the London Eye by climbing to the top of Primrose Hill.
A picturesque waterfall, rock pool, where koi carp dart beneath the surface and peacocks stalk past on the banks.
